r4M5zqkWsneNFRGeQWJWyQ.text: To anyone who loves to dine off the strip, this should be on your hit list. Chef Jamie has absolutely made a fantastic dining experience for locals. Music is the best at any local restaurant that I've ever heard. Beers are always changing if that is your type of thing. Wines are reasonable and will not break the bank. Atmosphere is 5.5. Her and her team created dishes that are social media friendly and give you something to talk about on Monday morning with your coworkers. There isn't anything about this restaurant that I would change except I wish it was closer to Chinatown where I hang out. =)

udFPWnpKxEgFuiK65tUX1w.text: Oh, no, here I go being an outlier, again.  I do not enjoy being the maverick, you know.  I much prefer it when I love the places that everyone loves, and hate the places that everyone hates (or finds "bleh.")  But though most people really enjoy their food here, it left me a little cold.   But let's put this in context: For the food the night we were there, it was a 2.5.  For the atmosphere, ambience, and service, a 5.  Thus, the average is 3.  First, the food.  We ordered raw oysters on the half shell, the octopus (grilled), and the Karage chicken as appetizers, along with craft cocktails, including the "Sunburn" drink which is tasty.  The oysters were quite tiny!  And they were overpowered by the lemongrass sauce.  And it did not gel well with the tomato-based cocktail sauce which was also offered.  It made the seafood taste too sweet and unbalanced.  The octopus, we didn't understand would be sooo spicy.  I don't mind heat, but it threw us off.  The body of the meat was also not as tender as I was expecting, and I thought the polenta bar (or whatever it was) was a bit too hard.  I didn't try the Karage chicken, but the way my friend was eating it, made me think she didn't like it much.    Same for the entrees when they came.  My whole fish, Trout, was terrific! Truly a stand-out.  BUT, it was swamped and overpowered by some overly, aggressively seasoned greens (red chard, perhaps) that really competed with the fish.  I had to rely heavily on the side of white rice (which was nice) to counteract it.  I mean, those greens were salty! Were they trying to get us to order more drinks? You just have to ask, guys.  And I felt bad for my dining companion, who ordered the short rib, but asked for salt and pepper, and then abandoned eating it and put her napkin in the dish.  Dessert was okay.  I got the apple bread pudding with ice cream.  Thank goodness for the ice cream.  Otherwise, it would have been way too cloying.  The pudding was more like a cake, and was too sweet and dense for my liking.  I tasted the apple, but it gave off "candied apple," to me, which is not a sophisticated flavor profile.  My friend got the chocolate cake which looked like the top of a bird's nest...so interesting!  (Did they borrow from the presentation that I have seen pictured from "Rose. Rabbit. Lie" by chance?)  But the taste was a bit off.  My pal just did not seem to enjoy it and only picked at it.  I tried it, and thought it was more of a cool concept than an enjoyable dessert.  The coffees ("Americanos") we ordered were fine, but a bit bitter; I would have preferred a straight cappuccino.  But we were offered only "Espresso" or "Americano."  Second, though, the ambience of the place is cool.  The black and white photographic mural is gorgeous, as is the wall of off-white empty frames.  Very on trend.  The service is superior.  Our server was solid (except for describing some dishes, and letting us know about the spice level of the octopus).  All of the staff (and manager, who came over) made us feel very welcome and special.  We had no complaints there whatsoever.  I will give this place another chance.  I really wanted to like its inventive food.  Maybe it was just an off night.  Plus, I understand that they change their menu from time to time.   I will re-review if I have more success with the next rotation.

OW1dXYbdIDmTpZDvUaFqNw.text: Finally had a chance to dine at Eater's 2017 Restaurant of the Year with a menu from the Chef of the Year.  It was a spectacular and enjoyable meal that begs for a return visit.  Actually came in on a whim, being in the area on a Friday night.  The parking is free, but the lot is small.  We walked in and were lucky to have been seated, as the entire dining area and bar were occupied - next time I'll make a reservation.  Also, try to keep parties small because, though the tables and chairs can be rearranged, the atmosphere better suited to intimate parties.    The very dim lighting stood out to me a lot.  I was able to read the menu, but others may not have it so easy.  Even the food, it was so dark that aesthetics of the plate and any vibrant colors were missed from being blacked out by shadows.  Starting out with an appetizer we went for the Thai Basil Shrimp Ceviche ($12).  It was delicious, fresh, and light.  A few bites that're great for sharing with a friend.  It is also one of the most popular dishes as per our server (I also saw it on neighboring tables around us).  When it came to the entree, I couldn't decide between the Pork Belly and the Confit, but our knowledgeable server told me that the menu changes with the season and as Summer is wrapping up, the Lemongrass Duck Confit ($25) will be removed.  The duck came out served in a large bowl.  The tender bone-in meat with crispy skin rested on top of a layer of couscous, broccoli, and sausage.  It was really a filling dish and did not disappoint at all.  Being off the Strip, it was nice to dine at a place in the neighborhood that felt like a high end Vegas-style restaurant.

2pDDGrC0OPOpwXUwhjXteA.text: This was my first time here.  Went there on a Wednesday night and the parking lot packed.  The restaurant was packed.  All a good sign.  When we walked in they asked if we had a reservation and we said no but we were able to sit at the bar.  We ordered Sea Bass, Short Ribs, Asahi and a dirty vodka martini.  All delicious but the short ribs needed a bit more flavor and wasn't as moist as short ribs should be.

Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Short Rib dinner

e4dy1pAR46gsjCosoBUiDg.text: A must eat when I am in town! Service, food, and ambiance all worth 5 stars. Recommend dining family style so you can try for than one dish!

bJbkLgLFTAn6D5DFrD82AQ.text: We dined here twice during Restaurant Week to sample the food and wine pairing.  The food did not disappointment and the restaurant gets busy with a lot of neighborhood business.  Call ahead to make your reservation.  Twice we ordered the deboned trout and it was done to perfection but the rice was a bit under cooked on the second time.  We also tried the rib eye (additional cost) and short rib and both were very good.  We plan to visit again to try their regular menu.

gqZHznkQXdGSAgNqGXTL5w.text: The Black Sheep is always busy! I finally was able to check them out and have to say the best part of everything was our server Hunter who really knew the menu and gave great suggestions. This Asian influenced spot wasn't what I expected food wise but definitely in a good way.  We had a few of their signature cocktails which were all delicious:  the brownstone has a brown sugar ice cube that melts as you sip. La Flama Blanca is very refreshing. We also had a black manhattan and the Rosita.  The oysters at The Black Sheep were the best oysters I've had in awhile. They have three offerings for toppings but I thought they were best plain. I did like the granita which was very sweet.  We did order a variety of appetizers and entrees and My recommendations on what I'd order again are the octopus, beef crisps, and the pork belly dish.  The octopus was very tender and delicious. It was not rubbery at all. I've never had octopus cooked to this almost fish like consistency before.  The beef crisps were phenomenal. I could snack on these forever or until my arteries explode. They get doused with a spicy and acidic sauce that makes every bite different.   My favorite entree was the pork belly. It looked very unassuming: a bunch of little carrots surrounding this hunk of bland looking pork belly next to some red noodles. This was really good though! The pork belly was tender and the noodles went there with the spice.  Some other dishes I'd pass on that we got were the duck prosciutto salad and the duck confit. I thought the duck prosciutto was okay. It really needed something tart or sweet as the strawberries didn't really add to it. The duck confit was just overwhelmingly sweet without other flavors.  We also got the cherries jubilee dessert which was a miss. It was overwhelmingly bitter with not enough balance. I think they should have burned more of the alcohol out before dousing the dessert with it.  Overall the good dishes, great cocktails, and amazing service made up for the couple of dishes we didn't enjoy. The service was great. We had our plates and silverware changed multiple times and our waters were always topped off.   I did only do four stars because of some of the mix ups. I'd recommend they really go for it with their use of Asian flavors they use. We had their Thai shrimp ceviche and it definitely had no Thai remnants in my opinion. It looked beautiful and the shrimp were nicely prepared but It tasted just like regular ol ceviche which was just okay.  It was a beautiful to look at but really just tasted like lime. The dish that really was good was the pork belly because it went there! It was super spicy but in the best way possible.

photos.caption: Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mr. Brownstone. Loved it.
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Duck prosciutto salad.
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Thai ceviche. Absolutely beautiful but lacked flavor. Papaya was very mild in sweetness.

U-ookv0pgq-M13EMnnewEg.text: You don't need to go to the Strip for a James Beard culinary experience.  Thank you Chef for a memorable birthday dinner! Intimate atmosphere, great service.  Highly recommended.

UQsqnLczxsD4FE-EXOl9Gw.text: This was a pretty awesome place to check out.  It was also located next to a spot I had been wanting to go to, Suzuya Patisserie.  I made sure to grab dessert first before dinner!  I truly enjoyed everything we ordered.  The first two were appetizers and the last two were the entrees, although it got to be a bit too heavy much toward the end.  Maybe because we had dessert first!  Here is what we got:  Salmon Skin Tacos Grilled Spanish Octopus Lemongrass Duck Confit Slow Braised Short Rib  The customer service was great, the food presentation was pretty unique and the dining experience was overall very awesome!  I highly recommend you to come here for a meal!

n3kVJfRF8bEgA7WfPEd9_A.text: How do we rate the food, when the bill came through and the restaurant charged us $2 for "Rocks?"     I've been told that the $2 is a standard surcharge for anything on the rocks.  I'm trying to rationalize the fact that they charged me $12 for one drink, then added $2 extra for "Extra pour".  Listen we got one ounce, and that's it.  I am just trying to rid this ridiculous way of charging customers.   It's Just another way to make a buck !!!   I truly have no issues paying more  If we actually had more liquor in our glass, and if our sever advised us that our one drink would now be $14.    Suggestion, charge $14 for the drink instead of $12, and let the new price absorb the $2 "Rock".   It really makes the restaurant search for profit, and puts your guests in an unfortunate position.     Regarding our meal.  The food  was good, and the deserts were excellent.     We did not have a reservation as it was a Wednesday,  the host recommended we sit at the bar and wait as all tables were spoken for.  But within a few minutes  somehow a table was available.  We were confused on what happened, as we just about to order a drink.  During the night the restaurant did not "Sell Out".  Again, suggestion, treat your guests as "A guest", make us feel welcome from the beginning.  We felt that we were more of an annoyance.   We are locals and did take the time to travel to your establishment.   OpenTable says Las Vegas currently has over 2278 restaurants, what makes The Black Sheep stand out?   Hmmmm!  I have visited The Black sheep a few times.   I don't know if we will return.   The prices are now getting similar to strip prices.

_noVPJvA_rjdJMfy3jXydA.text: Truly enjoyed the food here. The sunburn drink was super tasty.  Started out with imperial rolls..so good we ordered another one. There's a nice kick is spice to it. We had the short rib, rainbow trout, noodles, scallops. Every single dish was so good and there is so much flavor. I thoroughly enjoyed all of the dishes. We even started with a pear salad that had goat cheese and walnuts....so good  I highly recommend this place, I loved all of the appetizer and entrees.  For desert we tried a bread pudding and the tees leche chocolate cake. The tres leche was underwhelming. I don't think is order it again.  Highly recommend eating here.

AeW3u3Zxa9nHIM2wYcZ7Tw.text: #theblacksheep in #lasvegas is another fantastic #lasvegaseats and representative of why I love eating off the #lasvegasstrip  the #vietnamese (I use the term lightly) restaurant does not serve traditional #vietnamesefood but is phenomenal nonetheless (and paired with award winning drinks!) must tries! The best #happyhour $1 #oysters I've ever had (sweet west coast oysters) and #beeftartare  I wanted to try every single one of the drinks (they all sounded so good) but decided to save room for the #persimmonbreadpudding instead no regrets!!!

lGb750nMSQsgqxFZDv88_A.text: Finally tried this place - My foodie friends kept raving about it! Started off with the hot chicken, Vietnamese imperial rolls and the steak tartare. The imperial roll, was definitely my favorite.  Steak tartare was served on top of chicharrones -you can't go wrong with a salty crunch. The hot chicken was similar to boneless buffalo chicken wings but served with honey toast. If you're a fan of sweet and savory, then this is for you. My favorite dishes were the entrees. The scallops with kabocha polenta was Amazing!! Each bite was filled with so much flavor. The glass Vietnamese noodles, were just as delightful. It was mixed in with brussel sprouts, baby carrots and a sweet and spicy sauce. Unfortunately, the salmon skin tacos weren't available, which broke my heart since I love salmon belly. I will have to go back and try it. Overall, great fusion food with tasty drinks!

2OKvs5af8ydPPl6is8ceOw.text: A great disappointment. We had very high hopes as we love to support local establishments but this was a dreadful experience.  We were overcharged on drinks. Our server was clearly annoyed that we were ordering multiple appetizers(we'd never been and wanted to try out a bunch of items). When I say annoyed, imagine your teen huffing and puffing because they are told they can't go to the movies (eye-rolling, the aforementioned huffing, and arm crossing). We literally felt bad about being there, as if we were an inconvenience. I didn't get it as the items were all coming out at basically the same time and the total was far higher than if we'd each just had one entree. The food itself was bland with the exception of one item. It was apparent that the chef was really trying but maybe we just were there on an off night.  So the overcharging on the drinks was annoying but we didn't realize that until we were given the bill and at that point, I didn't want to deal with the server again so we just paid the thing and got out of there. This would have been a three-star except for the server. He really made a negative impression on us and we'll never go there again.

xwSUWA_o0DcsYFFEg9zfeQ.text: I call places like this "hipster food."  The ambiance is cool, the menu is innovative, the service is usually on point, and the food is well.. meh.   I ordered the grilled octopus, the NY strip special, and the cherries jubilee brownie.   This takes me back to the "hipster" term. I've found places like these try to be fancy with the dishes when the star of the dish ends up getting lost with all the flavors.   The octopus was lost in the sambal and the crispy rice that I couldn't tell what part was actually the octopus. The AMAZING dry aged steak was murdered with XO sauce that I literally scraped it off and put it to the side and actually saw another table do the same! They give you a piece not in sauce at all (photo included) and I could've just ate it happily like that. The brownie was unfortunately a little too hard our server gave us a steak knife to get in there.   The place is really good, but it's just too fancy for me. I like the meat to be the star and not all the craziness going on. I believe in less is more, but who knows I might make my way back to try other items as I'm told they change the menu often.

8Ho4j99q0CamnghgU8ghYQ.text: Oh wow! Where do I start....  AMAZING FOOD!!!!  AMAZING SERVICE!!!! And  AMAZING ATMOSPHERE!!!!!! I can't Waite to come back and try more of the dishes. If you are a fish person get the rainbow trout! It was perfect!!!

OZF3ITvSdu-0B_jy3HhT9Q.text: I love this place. Everything I have had there I have fully enjoyed . Especially my latest meal there which was for Sunday brunch with bottle less mimosas.  So yummy!

ExM9Jl0l3UgIfXd1fpNrXw.text: Saw a great Yelp rating and thought this would be a slam dunk.  For weeks, i assumed this eatery would impress the fam bam.  We ordered a bunch of apps to get a sample size of their flavors.  Imperial rolls - these were good but to give you perspective, Hawaii's Rice Place is vastly superior. Fried beef crisps..  same look & feel like a bag of pork rinds.  They are unique, I give it that much.  Perhaps it's the presentation, plating is plain. Salmon skin tacos...  sounded good on paper but missed on execution.  We ordered six and left three on the table. Ahi tartare...  tartare on their beef crisps.  Feels like it is missing something.  Add more to the recipe and you may have a winner. Crispy octopus was tender and delish.  My favorite app! Kim chi chicken karaage.  This was OK.  To be fair, we asked the kitchen to separate the spiciness on the side.  The dish likely works best when the chicken is cooked in their secret sauce.  Apps and entrees were like night & day.  The entrees were really good!  Wife had the short rib.  I had the seared scallops.  Mom had lamb.  All of those entrees were well plated and visually beautiful!  Flavor was also on point!  Main entrees rescued the underwhelming appetizers.  Our server was from Mililani and was patient with us.  He was fantastic!  Took time to explain in detail what his favorite dishes are and also thoroughly answered our question.  Great customer service!  Give this man a raise!  Again, to be fair, my party had diet restrictions--no spicy food.  Their menu is full of spicy dishes.  I wish I knew my family's food aversions before selecting this restaurant.

ZuqEYA-eFbC_t6YZsrmScw.text: loved it all..creative & delicious cuisine, cozy & modern ambiance and timely, professional service... a must try!   Put it on your calendar for your next special occasion meal!

1Om_75_SZjLRfxS-I_63Fw.text: Decided to give this place a try since they have the happy hour. I wish they extended the happy hours since it's only 1 hr long. I tried they oysters,  beers,  and a few items on their menu. Everything tasted only ok. We ordered the short braised ribs and it was a little dry. Their oysters were just ok. Not as fresh as I expected.... I also hope they have more beer selections on their happy hour menu and not so limited to just 2 types.

2CFp-RStv33CEMUl5GeFag.text: Their food was good but definitely overrated. This place is small and their wait staff needs improvement.

bUywSnZPrHYuRDGbezIDjw.text: We are blown away at some of the ambivalent reviews we've seen so far. This establishment which exists no more than 5 minutes away from my house is a gold mine. For walking in for the very first time tonight, we cannot express our ultimate respect and gratitude for what just happened in the last 2 hours. First and foremost, thank you to the bar, management, front of house and back of house team. As one unit, you are incredible to say the least. Ambiance A+++. Cute, intimate, and down to earth With that said... Let's proceed.   Drinks: perfectly and eloquently made by the main man MAX! "Mr. Brownstone," "Vietnamese coffee martini," and "Rosita" were completely delectable. Just watching him create was an appetizer with the drinks being the main course.   Food: Kumiai oysters with Thai chili and lemongrass granita- fresh, clean, salty and sweet. You'll want to take the sauce home.  Salmon skin tacos: 2 salmon skin tacos (literally) stuffed with salmon belly, Tabiko , shishito peopers and cilantro. Perfectly balanced crispy and juicy explosion in your mouth.  Fried beef crisps: beef tendons stretched and dried, then deep fried and dusted with Thai chili takin and chili lime. So fresh, hot, flakey and popping.  Grilled Spanish octopus: Chinese broc, crispy rice block, ginger sambal sauce and frisee salad. I've read some say it's chewy or rubbery. It's octopus people! Know it, love it, understand it. It changes with how it's prepared so if you love octopus, you'll love this here. Full of flavor and complex with just a little kick.  Vietnamese crepes: braised duroc pork belly, crispy pig ear salad, sprouts, and garlic vinaigrette. This was the killer. Recommended by DANNY, (the manager, server, host, busser, runner, definition of customer service) this dish was to die for. Came out first and will forever leave a lasting memory.   The descriptors for taste and value are weak. We know that. Why that is? It's because the menu changes every few months and if you don't go RIGHT NOW, it won't be available. The goal is to inspire you all to check it out. Judge for yourself but at least don't sleep on this personal invitation. Executive Chef JAMIE TRAN is a force to be reckoned with. If only I had been able to peel her away from the kitchen tonight to praise her for her talent and devotion... She is an artist and a mastermind. We wannnnnna take her home and feed her skittles.  Shout out to the ones not mentioned. Everyone was amazing and we can't wait to meet and greet soon.  - keep on keepin on!

w5culYUczukvOCJgzpAJug.text: I always love trying to restaurants when I'm in town. My friend told me about this New American restaurant with Vietnamese influence - Black Sheep so we decided to give it a try.   The decor of this restaurant is so different and unique. Love the huge wall with the decorative places. There is a good sized bar and enough tables to accommodate large parties. Our bartender was a sweetheart and I loved that she recommended her favorite dishes because every single one of them did not disappoint.   We tried a variety of drinks however my favorite was the "La Flama Blanca" - great choice for those who like a little spicy.   My other favorite drink was the Green Lightning - Matcha tea infused gin. I'm not usually a gin drinker but this really hit the spot.   For food: Oysters - must get because on top of the oyster is a lemongrass Thai chili kind of jelly that's just so different - it's like an explosion of flavor in my mouth.   Ahi tuna tar tar - 3 pieces, the tuna was well marinated and the texture was silky smooth on top of the crispy rice.   Vietnamese Imperial Roll - 4 pieces of spring roll deep fried. The inside is pork and shrimp and it's extra extra crispy which I love.   Bao Sliders - who doesn't love the white fluffy bun? It's a pork sausage patty and the jalopeno aioli was so good I wanted to ask for an extra side of the sauce. The lotus chips are very thinly slices and crispy.   Rainbow Trout - my FAVORITE dish. Don't worry about the bones because chef de-bones it for you. The sauce is to die for. It's a ginger and rice vinegar sauce and I'm going to be dreaming about it for forever because I would like to make this sauce at home.   And finally for dessert, this chocolate brownie madness - I forget what it's called but the cake is so moist and on top of that, they drizzle condensed milk all over. One bite and I wanted the plate to myself. This is not for sharing. Everyone needs to get their own.   I'm definitely telling my friends about this restaurant and I'm coming back here every time I visit vegas. Thank you Black Sheep!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dessert - chocolate brownie - the moist brownie ever and condensed milk drizzled over it
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My favorite dish ever - rainbow trout. The sauce is to die for
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ahi tuna tartar - seasoned perfectly

NKGp_HSIS52fyC2LyzkebQ.text: Love the decor of this place, very chic and modern, cute little place for a date I would say. Service was excellent...until they got busy. We arrived around 6 and they only had 2 other tables and a few people at the bar. We seated immediately, our server got us water and took our drink orders immediately. He explained the menu and made recommendations, food came out pretty quickly and he came back to check-in our us regularly. Towards the end of our meal was then they got busy, the restaurant filled up and it was clear they were under-staffed. I asked for a soda re-filled and waited about 15 minutes until I got it, we just asked for the check and left. Even though service lacked a little towards the end I would say service was really good. The 3 start is for the food.   Presentation was excellent, very instagram worthy. I think they have unique ideas and concepts but lacked flavors in my opinion.   Oysters - We got them with the spicy cocktail sauce which I liked and the Thai chili granita which I did not care for. But my biggest issue with these oysters as that they were very warm, like a couple degrees above room temperature. I am not an oyster expert or anything but I have always had oysters cold...these were so warm they feel like eating cheap Chinese buffet oysters. That totally killed the dish for me.   Crisply Octopus - Love the idea of fried octopus and really liked the curry sauce that came with it but the octopus itself was too tough and hard to eat. It is very lightly breaded but too tough to eat, doesn't have have chewy sharpness that octopus usually has.   Bao Sliders - These were so cute to look at! The buns were fluffy and sweet, love the quail egg on top, but even with the pork sausages and the aioli it tasted very bland. The flavors did not pop at all, I tasted the slight sweetness of the buns and the slight saltiness of the sausages, no strong flavor to hold everything together.   Salmon Clay Pot - Extremely disappointed with this dish. Big and delicous piece of salmon...the only good thing about the dish. The eggplant and the farro were so bland..none of us liked this dish. If they had some sauces on top or on the side that would have helped. Salmon is bland on its own, the farro and eggplant added to the blandness.   Duroc Pork Belly and Slow Cooked Short Rib - These two dishes were delicious. The meats melts in your mouth, so soft and sweet. Strong flavors, love the sticky rice that came with the pork belly. Very impressed with these two.   So out of the 3 appetizers and 3 main dishes I only enjoyed the two main dishes. I think this place has potential, they have interesting ideas but I think they need to work on adding more flavors to their dishes. Most of the dishes were bland and just did not satisfy my appetite as much as I would have liked.

0g-umFPWwm1HXbZwOLKXWA.text: Wow. Food here is just damn good. Salmon skin tacos; what an ingenious little appetizer. The octopus with polenta was so tender and tasty, the best I've ever had. My friend got the short ribs. I literally cleaned his plate because he couldn't finish it. Delicious. I had the scallops. Three large scallops in a cream sauce that just made me happy. Perfectly cooked. We are here on business for a week and will definitely be back to try other things on the menu.

UQ0krjXwSMpogh_kyoWLlQ.text: I really wanted to love this place. We wanted to try something different to celebrate our son getting his driver's license  The ambience and decor was very nice. Music was a little intense and kinda loud. Noise level was high.   We came on a Wednesday just before 9p. The place was full. It's small with about 50 seats total. So we waited about 10 minutes for a table.   We were seated by the door. The table was very wobbly. The server said he'd do something about it but he never did. My son had to keep his foot on the table stand throughout our meal. The server was nice but not very personable or attentive.   The appetizers were hit and miss. Wings were delicious but we didn't care for the hamachi crudo or the sliders. Hamachi was bland and the sliders had a weird off putting taste to it.   Our entrees were a lot better. We had the trout, pork Belly and braised short ribs. All the dishes were flavorful. My favorite was the trout.   My husband ordered old fashioned and he loved it. They have a pretty decent wine list. I wasn't drinking that night so I didn't try anything. We'll be back soon to give it another shot. Maybe come for their oyster special happy hour.

xHC_ihq13xllyNawzRv1UQ.text: This spot is unreal.  The food is amazing and the drinks are also spot on.  Salmon skin tacos, grilled octopus, deep fried trout, grass fed steak are all top notch incredible.  Super fresh and satisfying.  I never had an old fashioned until The Black Sheep.  I will say this, their version has me hooked.  Love this place!

bIYWsZdT0zx5x1yjKxOONg.text: Entering the restaurant comes with a very modern feel to an otherwise unnoticeable lot. Down the plaza from SkinnyFats, a Las Vegas highlight, the restaurant invites a more intimate crowd; black being the covering most of the restaurant's corners.   Greeted by the host and promptly seated, the service was quick to introduce the menu which consisted of a small but select menu. Unfortunately by no fault of the staff, the restaurant soon became overwhelmed. The full house caused the two waiters and single host to continually divide their attention: I was only able to see the waiter upon ordering and delivering my food, leaving the small glass of water I had continually empty.   Of the appetizers they had offered I selected the oysters and the sliders. Las Vegas has a plethora of Japanese, Vietnamese, and other Asian fusion that offer oysters; the Black Sheep's was about average at best. The salinity of the oysters were its biggest turnoff (Other than calling Sriracha a "Rooster Cock Hot Sauce"). The sliders, while small, do pack a delicious bite (Literally one bite).   My entree was excellent; the slow roasted short ribs upon gnocchi and ratatouille was nothing short of what I had expected from the location. The tangy entree is very balanced and fulfilling. My two dining guests and the hanger steak and the pork belly. While the hanger steak was presented beautifully with the corn, the steak was incredibly average. Though tender, the taste resembled $3 midnight steak from South Point; not bad per say, just not to the quality of flavor that the price point equivocates. The starch pairing with the dish was fantastic however. The Pork Belly tasted about as good as it looks.  The saving grace of the restaurant came from their Tres Leches dessert. The flavors were excellent, playing with a variance of levels of sweetness.  The place essentially gets a three stars due to a myriad of issues. While the place is decent for a meal, I simply did not enjoy the flavors presented in several of their dishes. The server, while incredibly kind and engaging, didn't have enough staff to help him work. Even after hanging in my card for payment, I had to wait an additional 4-5 minutes for it to be swiped out. I really wanted to like the place, unfortunately I can't.

photos.caption: Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oysters
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Slow Roasted Short Ribs
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sliders

3if9tc9FEZ5Jmz11JIkK0A.text: Hm I was pretty excited to check out black sheep when some friends told me about it.   Online pictures of their menu looked pretty good and promising at first to us.  We came around happy hour times at 5:00pm and ordered a couple oysters to start off. I'm very..ehem, VERY picky when it comes to oysters. If I get a tint of fishy taste I don't think I really enjoy them at all. Especially after having such an amazing fresh oyster experience in San Francisco, I just can't seem to find a place as good.  The oysters at black sheep aren't the most perfect ones, they're mediocre id say, but the thing I didn't like about them is that they were really salty; probably because they sit in a bed of salt for presentation. But it really distracted me from enjoying their sauces or really much of anything., even when I tried to rinse them off with my water.  Next I also tried the whole trout. The char is pretty good and has a nice flavor sauce on it. It was probably the best part of the dish, but I felt the trout didn't taste as fresh as I was initially expecting. It sort of had a little bit of a frozen fish taste to it. But it wasn't bad I suppose overall. It also comes served with a bowl of rice and in a pretty decent sized portion for what you pay.  A friend of mine ordered the chocolate cake dessert towards the end of our meal. It had a decent flavor and wasn't too sweet which is a nice touch considering that chocolate can be overwhelmingly sweet at times, but I felt the texture was a little hard for a cake. I guess I was expecting a more soft and moist cake,so it was very different.  The last thing I remember trying was one of their cocktails which isn't offered on happy hour, called the sunburn. This was probably one of my favorite orders. It had a nice light refreshing taste and very present grapefruit citrus note. It's nice and sweet for a summer sipper.  Our service was pretty good as well, both our host and server were polite in refilling our water cups and the owner came back to check up on us and inform us about their menu maybe 3-4 times.  I felt black sheep was a pretty good place to try if you've never experienced it, but taste wise I didn't really think it was all there for me unfortunately.

lrgj9DVmX1NjisXwCQI41Q.text: Wow.... best off the strip meal I've had in vegas.   The cocktails are yummy and we ordered 4 appetizers and a couple oysters rather than ordering 2 entrees because everything looked so good and we wanted to try different flavors.  The salmon skin tacos and smoked octopus are insanely good.    I will definitely be back here on my next vegas trip!!!!

UynEjW5RL2FDnFiQ_AK0bA.text: Went for happy hour oysters this evening as we've been there several times before.    Got there at 4:55 and the door was unlocked.   Their posted opening time is 5 pm.  We were greeted or shall I say "ungreeted" by who we later learned was the manager.  Told that they were not quite open yet, they were still setting up, the bar was not ready so told to leave and come back in 10 minutes.   She also asked if we had a reservation which we did not.  She acted like it was an imposition for us to be there.   We left and debated going in but decided that after going out of our way to go there for HH oysters and then dinner, we'd go in.   Interesting as there were only two other tables taken while we were there.   Worse after ordering, told they stopped the HH oysters a month ago.   We had checked on the web to confirm their HH time before going in!   They told us it's no longer on their website.   The host and our waitress were pleasant but not sure if we'd go back or ever recommend this place again.

photos.caption: Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oysters

c65C0hWdZZ8f8hNlty0aIw.text: Duck confit, sliders, and the hot chicken. Don't think about it, just get them. Throw in some Stags Leap and you're basically going to own the town after.

92rpZsicre-InZzswF3OIw.text: Excellent inventive dishes, unique taste.  A meal that is just a party for your mouth... And fairly healthy as well!  We had: Starters -salmon skin tacos (get these! We had 2 orders - they are small, but plated so well and amazingly tasty!) -Vietnamese imperial (pork and shrimp spring) rolls (great flavor combination, served in a bed of frisee salad)- no dipping sauce, but none needed -octopus (excellent spicy sauce with asparagus and brilliant plating) -bao sliders (so tasty, quail egg and aioli adding great moisture- bun is nothing special, but that wasn't why we ordered the sliders anyway)  Entrees -salmon entree (tasted fine, but not my favorite of the night.  The accompaniments- red quinoa, tomato, a green were tasty -slow cooked short rib (so tender, with just a few (wish there were more!) kimchi cucumbers, and dumplings)  Desserts -warm brownie with marshmallow, chocolate, raspberry, pecans (which is sort of a deconstructed brownie- brownie with marshmallow on top and the other parts are scattered around the plate and your goal is to eat a bite with all the components- quite nice!) -Tres Leches with Vietnamese icing and regular white icing on the side (not nearly as sweet or chocolatey as the other dessert, but lovely and simple and a nice ending to a fine meal)  Highly recommended.  We booked reservations weeks in advance as we read about Jamie Tran and didn't want to miss her in action during a recent visit to Vegas.  Now I look forward to following her in the future.  Price point is very affordable- most starters are ~$8-12 and many entrees ~$23.  Don't miss this restaurant- well worth coming off the strip.  Or if you are a local, you're just lucky... go and enjoy her culinary genius tonight! (And then again tomorrow, because I would!)  Congratulations Jamie- you are most definitely a playful rebel in the culinary world and you've gained several fans tonight!  Thanks for the show! (Please come to the Bay Area of CA soon!)

Y9BThlrGSJrHUaJ34S_YDw.text: Pretty good so far! Here for Happy Hour and the Bao Sliders were delish!!! Wine is great and so is the Short Ribs! Definitely will return! Great service too!

photos.caption: Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delish! Short Ribs!

tNly4kFbEHP3BYZyWIdyNQ.text: Oysters during 5-6pm Happy Hour are only a buck ($1), YUM!   The service was attentive, personable and friendly.   I visited on Fathers Day and they had a special rib dish. Oh my. It was 5*.   The sliders were absolutely gourmet deliciousness on a stick.   I look forward to my next visit. Great Vietnamese food.

i-HrSbgkd6_vTS-QV1swfA.text: This place has the potential to be something great. The menu is interesting enough to make me want to come back for more. However the only down side that I had was the portion size (me being the fat ass I am).. We ordered:  Bao Sliders - Two small sliders packed with flavor. The bao was so soft and fluffy and the whole thing was like a mini gourmet high quality egg mcmuffin..  Braised Duroc Pork Belly - Fire....it was juicy and savory and had that umami quality with the earthiness below it and the fluffiness and light air quality on top.   Scottish King Salmon 'Clay Pot' - This was a pretty well executed dish with the salmon being extra smooth and melt in your mouth type salmon.  There are a lot of other dishes on the menu that we are looking to try so we will most def come back soon!

jPlcqdlTDbQrMokr_ZQLAg.text: First we ordered a bottle of their basic Malbec....super tasty.   Then a beet salad to share for a starter. Crazy good.   I had the flank steak steak and it was absolutely great.   My wife got the Rib-eye.....hands down it made my flank steak taste like a new cook had made it. The waiter (Shepherd....no joke.....that's his name) told us the rib-eye was better, but I wanted for us not to try more than one thing.   Now the last name of the Chef is Tran....so we were educated enough to think their may well be some Asian flair with our food. We were not disappointed!!!!  As I said. Flank steak is great. The Rib-eye is stunning. One of the best Rib-eyes I have ever had. The meat was perfectly cooked.....the sauce and sides to this....sun-choke.... yum.....slayed me. Shepherd says that the pork belly beats the Rib-eye......next time.   We had an extra glass each of the Malbec with dessert. Fantastic finish.   Please go if you're hungry and in the area. This place is fantastic and I'm a little ticked cause we used to live round the corner.   Not going to stop us going back though, even though it's farther afield.

hAC0gMn20cogBSqow2brMw.text: While the food was good I was completely deterred by our arrival. Yes, the parking lot is small and sucks (it's a very busy small strip mall with limited parking). We arrived at the door mid-week 6:30-ish and walked into a half empty restaurant. We waited and were finally acknowledged with a snooty "do you have reservations?"  Um no but we were just 2 and, again there were ALOT of empty tables. The "Host" made us feel almost guilty for not having reservations, huffed and looked around the room. After a few awkward minutes we were shown to (literally) the table just to put left (against the wall with one seat at the door). We reviewed the menus and waited. While we waited I looked around and realized we could be the parents (if not worse) of anyone in the establishment (patrons or staff)   Our server was very accommodating with recommendations and we obliged with most of those. Again the food was good but the portion sizes are on the light side (especially for what you are paying).    What infuriated me the most (and keeps this rating as low as it is) is the fact that the majority of the empty tables remained so throughout our meal and yet we were made to feel guilty or an imposition for arriving without a reservation.

_4I89TStXgm_USG0igE37w.text: We finally came here late last night.  I'd been wanting to try the food here, Vietnamese fusion.  I remember it was a poke bowl spot that didn't last longer than 6 months.  I have to say, I think it's the location and not the right type(poke bowl) for this plaza.    Last night my husband wanted to eat somewhere before 10 PM.  I was browsing OpenTable and saw that The Black Sheep was still open and only a mile from our house.  I booked it and we came within 15-20 minutes.  Since I booked our table online, when we walked the guy at the front asked me by my first name.  Attentive service since we walked in.  We both really like the vibe here, dim lighting and the music.  Love the decor and how clean it is.  The server was very knowledgable of their dishes with all the ingredients.  This is very helpful for food allergy people.  We ordered a lot of appetizers and one entree.    SALMON SKIN TACOS (I liked it, husband didn't, he thought the skin was weird.) AHI TUNA TARTARE (We both loved it, fresh, simple.) VIETNAMESE IMPERIAL ROLLS (Liked the presentation, but not much flavors, only the strong pickled veggies..it was salty and too sweet for us.) CRISPY MEDITERRANEAN OCTOPUS (We'll have to try this dish again next time.  The way the server describe it to us, it came out differently.  They took care of this dish for us.  To me it was little chewy, like only battered.  I couldn't really taste the octopus, very char tasting like burnt.  We ate most of it, trying to figure out the ingredients in it.  The curry sauce was super thick, lots of cumin in it.)  FRIED WHOLE RAINBOW TROUT (My husband thinks this dish was ok.  I personally really liked it.  I didn't eat the stuff under the fish, since I'm allergic to soy.  The minimum the soy intake the better for me.  The fried fish part really reminds me of my mother's home cooked dish. It's simple and tasty.)  I had the common law cocktail, it was good, little too sweet for me though.  If I end up getting this one again, I'll ask for less sweeten.  Overall, I'm happy with our choices.  Looks like a great spot to come grab drinks at the bar.  We're looking forward to come here again.

czFmJ3fV6BDtrYWq61voVg.text: Let start by saying who ever is a bottomless mimosa fanatic this place is for you! $20 bottomless mimosas with choices from a mimosa, bellini or rose and you can switch it out or stick to one type. Jamie our server never left our glasses empty and was very patient with our table cause 2 of our guests were running 30mins late.  Jaime gave guys great recommendations and always kept us update especially when the kitchen was having a shortage on souffle pancake batter and was trying to perfect it prior to serving it! i ordered the french toast and my boyfriend ordered the brisket benedict! Both were well portioned and absolutely amazing! We will definitely be back for Sunday brunch soon!

photos.caption: Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Brisket Benny
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. French Toast

QexdLQj_EYYbBR7hWpNaCA.text: Creative menu with decadent plating that will make you feel like you are dining at a Michelin star restaurant. The chef has an amazing pallet to be able to come up with a fluid mix of flavors.   I take away a star because they need to work on inventory management. When we got there I wanted to have a gin cocktail and the duck (which was recommended), but when we got there, they were out of duck AND ingredients for the cocktail I wanted. Just my luck.  I'd suggest calling ahead for the duck to make sure they have some. Regardless, I look forward to going back and getting to taste the items I wanted to try the first time!    Stay tuned...

yC3ABjWw_y4BBkkx3CdUsQ.text: The Black Sheep located near Rhodes Ranch on Warm Springs in Southwest is a neighborhood restaurant that offers a tasty contemporary spin on new American cuisine with a Vietnamese twist or two.  Chef Jamie Tran and partners opened The Black Sheep in 2017 and promptly won the Eater awards forBest New Restaurant and Best Chef.   2 years in The Black Sheep has a comfortable stylish vibe and offers excellent, creative, tasty dishes that are in the same league with the best restaurants in Las Vegas. At dinner on Saturday July 13 we enjoyed and shared a special Summer Peach Salad and house speciality Salmon Skin Tacos to start. Entrees were the Whole Fried Trout and the Lemongrass Duck Confit. All dishes were appealing to the eye, offered lovely aromas and were delicious. We didn't stay for dessert this time but will be back.   The staff was great. Kudos to our server Hunter. Everyone...guests and staff were clearly having a good time.  Two thumbs up to The Black Sheep. We're already looking forward to next time!

Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lemongrass Duck Confit
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Whole Fried Trout

Q8JXubnKFkmE0BdrpJESOg.text: Attractive mom and pop sized restaurant with good service and tasty dishes..but I left here still hungry..  Black Sheep Ambiance & Service:  Gorgeous decor complete with hanging light bulbs, attractive full size bar, dark wood and dim lighting definitely gives a contemporary classy vibe good for a date night.  They pack the tables close so it's a tight fit for everyone like a resto in Manhattan.  fyi.  Our server was friendly but we had to track her down later as the place filled up quickly for the dinner rush.  She was trying her best.  Black Sheep Cuisine:  Me & the BFF shared the: Steak Tartare, Vegan Glass Noodles, Short Rib and the Bread Pudding.  The steak tartare his minimal steak on the dish but was tasty.  The glass noodles was a great side dish as the noodles and veggies were both fresh.  The short rib was tender packed with flavor but was an appetizer dish serving size.  I'm not really a bread pudding guy but Black Sheep's was top notch and I'd order it again.  Were all the dishes social media friendly, creative and tasty? Absolutely yes.  Were the serving sizes on the smaller side for the price leaving me still hungry after the meals ?  Absolutely yes.  Would I still come back and try more tasty dishes because it's also a cool scene. For sure!  These are the cards you're dealt at the Black Sheep, play them as you wish.  Enjoy!

Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Short Rib

5-kfHy_qMc1m-qFfjltoJg.text: Some of the best food I have ever had in Vegas.  I came in for my first time with my boyfriend and the hostess turned out to be the owner and chef Jamie. Love when a owner wears all the hats.  Every single thing I put in my mouth at the Black Sheep, I loved. Some of the most unique, flavorful, and satisfying dishes I have ever had. I'm hungry just thinking about it. Ended up going a second time two weeks later - please note that I don't even live in Vegas but will go out of my way when I'm in town to eat here.  Appetizers: - Steak Tartare - incredible and fun prezo - Ahi Tuna Crudo - delicious. Served over a delicious gazpacho. - Black Sheep 'Hot Chicken' - holy shit. Just order it. Wow. - Bao Sliders - my least favorite of the appetizers but still incredible - Vietnamese Imperial Rolls - must. Get.  Entrees: - Lemongrass Duck Confit - one of the most delicious medleys of food I've ever had. The couscous is to DIE for - Slow Braised Short Rib  Wine: Riva Leone, Barbaresco Piemonte  And whiskey shots with Chef Jamie of course.

vhIYRrW6ZcJ4LjmASUjBag.text: Ahhhh-mazing. If you love good food and haven't tried this amazing place yet, well get in your car and drive to the Black Sheep. You are missing out on so much fun flavor and fun dishes.  The salmon skin tacos are perfect, they have inspired me to actually cook more with salmon skin.  Also, the short rib is out of this world, nice and tender with a punch of flavor.  Cheers to Black sheep for the amazing food, service, and atmosphere.  I will be back.

9CGoA5n_zHCk-KUeDgKQ_Q.text: Right off the bat, super cute decor! Cute little neighborhood restaurant with great reviews!   I personally wasn't a fan because I felt like every dish we ordered had both sweet and savory comfort style flavors. One bite was enough for me with each plate! But that's just my opinion! I know tons of people that think otherwise!! And once again, in my opinion, the cost for the flavor was not entirely worth it, but I'm glad we tried it because we heard great things about this place!   Just because it wasn't my cup of tea, doesn't mean this review should sway anybody! Unless you're like me and prefer sweet and savory apart on separate plates

CvyjYl0pvogpHbFbmzYJyg.text: Nailed it. Top to bottom great meal. Great service. Fantastical flavors and the drinks make my liver quiver. Can't wait to come back as I think my wife won tonight's meal with the braised lamb belly with harissa yogurt. We started with the salmon skin tacos and tuna crudo and I'm still dreaming of the salmon skin tacos today.  Ingenious delivery. I got the short rib with horseradish risotto and it was lights out yummy. Made for an excellent "heat up breakfast" as well the next day. Location is warm and easy to get in and out. Will definitely be back.

Zom4OwK2HktvFGvn8q3PlQ.text: This was by far my favorite restaurant week restaurant this year. I come here all the time due to its excellent service and perfect fusion of asian flavors of many cultures. They draw inspiration from Vietnamese, to Thai, and even Korean flavors. Additionally, I love how the restaurant looks inside. This year Black sheep has a vast array of choices on their menu and even provided and opportunity for an upgrade. Of course this is what I opted for. My order consisted of ahi tuna crudo, a korean inspired kimchee steak, and lychee cheesecake. Everything was amazing. From the delicate citrus flavors of the crudo and well-blended kimchee and steak main entree. This restaurant has only been improving since I first ate here. I am for sure a customer for life at the restaurant.

SAPF4__ddJ3or_kdSeddLQ.text: The oysters here used to be super amazing and they also had happy hour oysters too.   Their portions are really small so the bill became very pricey for us at the end.  2 dozen oysters and a small salad plus a drink came up to be $100 and up.   I always thought their dishes are on the sweet side.  But there aren't many decent place nearby.    3 stars because I wasn't impressed with the oysters.   Some were just alright.  There are few places in town like Soho, Izakaya go and .... Served better oysters.   Or maybe I simply went at the wrong day for oyster feast.

CmSx6mNEc7p-S8aGBk5BwQ.text: Unique Menu, Good Service, Friendly staff   Went here on a whim before a Christmas party. Great selection of wine and cocktails. We sat at the bar   Food was Well thought out and not cookie cutter like everywhere else. They change the menu often so I would come again just to try everything out!   In a strip mall and plenary of parking, inside is small and quaint

6aHwxTmUTW_s5yqJlWeMFQ.text: Came here for a weeknight dinner with some girlfriends. The place has a very chill vibe. It is smaller with around 20 tables and a small bar. We ordered a bunch of apps to share. The ones that stood out and make me want to back for more are the crispy beef skins & boa buns. For dessert we ordered the chocolate tres leches cake. Three words to describe this place; chill, casual & welcoming. I am already planning on coming back for a casual date night with hubs.

5WkmXHbpERiK8TaLdj956A.text: Long, too long as it turns out, on my To Do list, we finally had dinner at this restaurant during our recently concluded vacation.  My wife and I commenced the dining festivities with poached Bartlett pear salad that included whipped goat cheese, crispy prosciutto, candied walnuts and basil vinaigrette. Truly a yummy for both eye and tummy.    My wife's FABULOUS entree was seared U-10 diver scallops nestled atop kobocha polenta with tossed pine nuts and tamari butterscotch sauce.  Oh I wonder wonder could this be duplicated at home?    Not to be outdone though I was, I ordered pan seared, crispy skin sea bass served over cavatelli with asparagus, dan dan sauce and hen of the woods mushrooms.  OMG! Who would believe I with sagging skin actually enjoyed the crispy skin.     We concluded the meal, though most was eaten by my wife, with a scrumptious tres leches with dark chocolate sponge cake. Did I mention it was lip smacking good?  Service by Joel proved to be just as good as the food he served.    A dining experience par none on our 14 day vacation.

Vw6T2yu5cBkA6gpmWpvk5A.text: This place is a gem! It took us 15-20 minutes to get here from the Strip, and it was a worthwhile trip. It was relaxed, friendly, and earnest without the glitz and sometimes soul-lessness of the big Strip establishments.   Our appetizers got us off to a strong start. The grilled Spanish octopus was cooked perfectly and nicely seasoned. The steak tartare had a surprisingly bold sauce, which I enjoyed. My entree, the lemongrass duck confit, was incredible; it was so full of flavor and the duck was very tender. My husband enjoyed his slow braised short rib, and I also liked my friend's fried whole rainbow trout.   Service was very good and helpful when we had a hard time deciding on dishes. The price is quite good given the quality of food. I highly recommend this place and hope I get to come back!

b7U5LV5S95nN_2z6lwxjoA.text: Chef Jamie Tran is brilliant!!! Her food is AMAZING and the staff is so professional and courteous!  With every dish that comes, the staff explains the dish which makes you even more excited to try it!! :) I appreciate the neat ingredients and attention to detail in the food!!   The Black Sheep has a rotating seasonal menu.  There are some mainstays it seems, but then some new items pop up so it is always a fun surprise to come here!!!  What to order if you can't order the whole menu:  SPANISH GRILLED OCTOPUS- the most tender, melt in your mouth octopus!  BLACK SHEEP "HOT CHICKEN" - karaage chicken smothered in a beautifully red, kimchi gochujang sauce!! It is on top of a thin slice of honey toast!  Mustard seeds and perfectly pickled cucumber slices cut the grease and heat!!    SEARED U10 DIVER SCALLOPS- everything about this dish (and all the dishes here for that matter) is perfect!! Kabocha polenta??!? Say whaaaat??  Creamy polenta goodness and three scallops seared to perfection!! Yesssss!!  BRAISED LAMB BELLY (can't remember the official menu name) - didn't know lamb belly existed until I had this dish. It sat perfectly cooked on top of mashed potatoes with flageolet beans, carrots, and crisp, fried baby beet slices!  The lamb belly was a hearty chunk of tender meat that wasn't gamey at all!    FRIED BEEF CRISPS - a must order!  The first time I was here, we saw the table next to us get it and had to order it for ourselves!  It is fried tendon!! I didn't even know you could do this with tendon!! ***Mind blown***  CHOCOLATE TRES LECHES CAKE - not too sweet, but just right!!!  Cream is poured on top and micro mint greens add a unique touch to it!!   The Black Sheep is one of the rare restaurants where you can probably eat your way through the whole menu and not be disappointed!! Have I done this? No, but now I think I will.

photos.caption: Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seared diver scallops!! Dive into mmm, mmm, mmm goodness!!!
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lamb belly, get in my belly!!
Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled Spanish octopus~~ the most tender grilled octopus everrrr!!

PfWFhvGDgqO8apHBMFzHEQ.text: This is a gem in a strip mall WAY off the strip.  The food was just sublime. We ordered some Mana from the heavens known as fried beef strips.  Oh my god.  It's served hot, and the server pours a garlic sauce on it and you hear it crackle.  As if that weren't the absolute best way to start the meal, we offered the short rid that came with sauteed baby beets and.....wait for it.... horseradish risotto.  Good lord. It was unreal.  Flavors bombard you as if  in a totally coordinated symphony.  We topped the meal with a chocolate tres leches.  Wow.  Just wow.  But noooo I can't stop there.  The BEST part of the experience was meeting the owner and head chef.  She was absolutely enchanting, after meeting her, honestly, whatever I was served would have been awesome.  Her personality is super bubbly, fun, sweet...and her passion for the food is really evident in her menu.  Super duper recommend this place ..shop local, eat local

4Z4vW-dsmW7EQ_hcMsk8iA.text: Just moved down the street and i have to say Im glad this is here. The food is just perfect. From the lamb to the duck to the beef tartare. Just f**king amazing overall. The plates are definitely better shared. Order one of their cocktails to pair. The food comes fairly quickly too.

fResiRzq9KkxPx9-6VhJCw.text: I'm really upset this place doesn't have 5 stars. It's BRILLIANT and will even go as far to say, if you dont like this place, then you're just (food) ignorant! I had a huge dinner here a few nights ago and can't stop both raving to others about this place and thinking about the food! Can someone give this place three michelin stars?! Because it's well worth the detour!  Every. Single. Plate. was incredible. The flavors were all so different and unique. It's clear they spent a lot of time creating this menu and perfect each dishes' flavor profile  Service was also friendly and attentive. We sat at a table. I heard bar service can be...a different experience lol  1. salmon skin tacos - so cool that the taco shell is actually just salmon skin fried in the shape of a taco! good sourcing of their raw fish 2. octopus - cooked well though i wish it has some char. Super savory dish while remaining well balanced 3. steak tartare - the meat is placed nicely on some fried, crispy pieces of "beef crisps" so it takes all the work out for you! the beef crisps alone are super yummy and flavorful, definitely added well to the raw meat. Ugh I want to be eating this dish again as I'm thinking about it and describing it 4. Fried whole rainbow trout - A MUST GET!!!! the fish comes boneless, which is amazing that you don't have to deal with all the small bones. Comes in a very salty, savory sauce. The sauce alone with rice was so good! The fish has a nice crispy shell to compliment the tender white meat inside. 5. slow braised short rib - comes on a corn fritter which is amazing alone and also paired with the tender meat. There are "korean rice cakes" in this dish which are like bigger, savory boba balls - I really enjoyed them! 6. Grass fed rib eye. The meat was good but I think what stood out for me on this dish was their mushrooms in the wild rice! I thought the mushrooms were soooo good and the flavor really came through in each bite of rice. I'm obsessed 7. Tres leches cake - A MUST GET. The cake is really soaked and is almost a custard flavor. SO DELICIOUS. there are puffs of cream around this dish and theyre two different flavors - coffee and vanilla - done so well! There's a chocolate "nest" on top, so think thin chocolate pieces which was itself good; i didnt confirm, but it tasted like dark chocolate because it wasn't super sweet which complemented the sweet cake very well 8. Persimmon bread pudding with house made ice cream. I could've done without as I've had better bread pudding, but it was still good and I enjoyed the persimmon flavor. The ice cream is interesting bc it was vanilla flavor, but they opted for a more sorbet-y finish rather that a super creamy ice cream which complemented the rich bread pudding super well 9. Got a cocktail, can't remember what it was lol but it was definitely a craft cocktail and unique. Had a pepper in it which carried a kick

photos.caption: Photo of The Black Sheep - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salmon skin tacos- super yummy!

Z9688MQiSuM2y6x6ryrcwA.text: Soon celebrating two years serving Spring Valley, an area notoriously lacking for Chef-driven Restaurants despite nearby hospitals and offices that should theoretically sport a crowd in search of quality, Sunday Brunch once again attested to The Black Sheep's uniqueness in a market otherwise littered by the mundane.  Tucked away at the corner of Durango and Warm Springs, nearby closures including The Goodwich and Paid In Full proving the Southwest a difficult place to get a foothold, it is immediately on entering The Black Sheep that diners realize there is something different about the space, a mural and organic flourishes giving the room an upscale feel while the Bar stocked in Top-shelf Spirits suggests a Mixology program ready to make a good impression.  Toqued by Jamie Tran, years working with Charlie Palmer, Vincent Pouessel and Daniel Boulud giving the Chef a firm command of French technique applied across flavors from her Vietnamese heritage, guests are invited to order Beverages including bottomless Mimosas while perusing a list of thirteen plates ranging savory to sweet - and often a combination of each.  Featuring smart and convivial service, something co-owner and operator Andy Hooper has assured since day one, it was declining Booze in favor of store-bought Orange Juice and Coffee from Lavazza that things started off quickly, four tiny Pastries for $8 not exactly a highlight as none appeared to be made on-site, though warm Strawberry Preserves helped and would be better served with just Bread and Butter.  Hungry enough to order all but Oysters or Steak and Eggs, two items hard to make unique no matter how talented a Chef, it was instead recalling Chef Tran's impeccable charred Peaches from 2017 that proper plates began with Smokey Heirloom Beets and Poached Pears, the former accompanied by Yogurt and charred Crumbles that play well off Candied Walnuts while the latter trends light, only to be punctuated intermittently by bites of Blue Cheese and Pecans.  Deferring progression to the kitchen, Jamie's cheerful personality still intact despite long hours in tight quarters, 'course' two arrived by way of Chicken Karaage turned-down from her version featuring Kimchi, each bite crispy and balanced by Waffles that sop-up a combination of Mustard Seeds and Syrup while The Black Sheep's baked Pancake comes at the bargain price of just $9 for something easily sharable as an Entree or Dessert.  Resetting share plates and refilling Drinks during a short pause, the overhead soundtrack drifting from Tone Loc to GnR and then Drake, it was in another style of Pancake, this time two-for-$9, that Brunch's best item was offered, a combination of Duck and Asian Pear complimented by Acid touching every part of the palate while Chef Tran's Vietnamese Imperial Rolls accomplish similar with a bit of lingering heat.  Again changing pace with a slice of French Toast, the removal of Herbs better allowing ground Sesame Seeds to shine amidst Berries and Brandy Syrup, those looking for a great Omelet need look no further than "Melody's" offered with either Short Ribs or house-smoked Salmon, the Fish selected largely for its novelty and beautiful beside Mushrooms while Chef Tran's Hash Browns are anything but ordinary thanks to both their crisp texture and complex spicing.  Finishing with one more cup of Coffee and fresh utensils, appetites sated and the room approximately half-full, it was opting for Short Rib over Salmon that The Black Sheep's Benny outperformed most thanks to not only the Meat but its interplay with Lime Hollandaise while Jamie's Chilaquiles eschew Meat in favor of earthy Red Sauce brightened by fresh Cheese, tangy Cream and a fried Egg broken by the guest to help Tortillas remain crisp.

z3fZozDte4eK0LMbw1daPA.text: My boyfriend and I have been wanting to try The Black Sheep for a while due to the amazing reviews this place gets. It definitely lived up to the expectations!  First of all, our server, Danielle, was great. She was attentive, informative, and very hospitable.   We got there for the happy hour and got the $1 oysters, they were very fresh and delicious. The granita they serve with them was amazing.  For our next course, we got the salmon skin tacos and bao sliders, both delicious. We got the short ribs to split as an entree, it was AMAZING; tender and flavorful. The dumplings that came with it were fantastic. For dessert, we got the tres leches and again, it was fantastic.  We will definitely be back. :)

tvdFbRR5oLyrFqI-UdGLSg.text: Boom! This place is dynamite! Chef Jamie is incredible. She's from a Vietnamese family and classically trained in French cuisine. The result is an incredibly complex, well thought out and balanced menu. I can't say enough about this spot. The lamb belly and beef crisp are two dishes I'll be taking about for days. Well done chef, well done.

iFC4D_vbHmbhN2GXfCcnHg.text: AhMazIng!!  A foodie paradise! Everything was flavorful, balanced menu... something for everyone! Great service and cool vibe! Ask for Rich..He is the psychotic awesome waiter we had!

4v29TmInaaeIpSWaLEaeww.text: Found this gem a year ago and ate here again two nites ago on our latest trip to LV. We have eaten all over the world at many of the finest restaurants, and the the food at this place is superb. The chef has created some of the best dishes we ever eaten! Clever, and extremely delicious! Well worth the trip off of The Strip!

f5cY-BiJ51O33efgcY-SLA.text: Had such an amazing date night at the black sheep! Atmosphere was cozy and intimate, but also had some cool industrial vibes. We started out with the imperial rolls which were delicious and we shared the short ribs entree. We were completely blown away on how amazingly tender the meat was (A+) and how all the flavors and sauces perfectly complemented each other. (I'm usually not a huge fan of kimchi but I absolutely loved the kimchi cucumber side.) We ended the night win the chocolate sponge cake with tres leche sauce, which was the right amount of sweet you'd want after dinner. Will totally come back here again and again to try out the rest of the menu!

E0JnFdFjGBAeBEOsK3KADA.text: Contemporary, Americanized Vietnamese seems to be the thing.  Me likey!  And I am talking about food.  Stop it!  Good originality and creativity with punchy flavors.  Perfect to pair with a few drinks.  Straight to it, crack chips, AKA beef crisps are a must order. Think chicharons but with the flavor of beef. Instead of skin, air dried tendon, deep fried beef tendon dusted with cayanne. Good alone, great when splashed with the accompanying citrus vinegar sauce.  The bao sliders, a must.  Finally something other than boring braised pork with hoisin.  An in-house made, "Asian" flavored pork sausage patty, oily in all the right ways, topped with a fried quail eggs and crispy shallots, greens, all on a bao "bun", slathered in spicy jalapeno aioli.  The pile of accompanying lotus chips so addicting.   Tuna tartare, would be ordinary if not for the controlled use of a spicy, aromatic chili citrus oil and salt as the only seasoning. Micro cilantro adds a hint of flavor.  Unlike poke, nothing gets in the way of the fishes flavor. Crispy rice crisps, on which the tartare is sat, great texture.  The oysters have bits of lemongrass citrus jelly in each. Zesty and perfectly matches the briny bivalves.  Mains are more straightforward.  The rice flour dusted, deep-fried whole rainbow trout with accompanying ginger and red wine vinegar sauce, solid.. The stand out, Scottish salmon cooked in clay pot. Smoked eggplant is a brilliant foil to the rich fish. The fresh plum salad, refreshes the pallet after every bite. The only thing it could do without is the farro (personal preference).  While not everything is perfect; the imperial rolls, not very crisp and oily, the braised short rib, tender and flavorful but the accompanying gnocchi, pasty and become stodgy with the squash ratatouille, in general very good.  Tip: HH 5 PM to 6 PM with $5 wine, $4 craft beer, and $1 fresh oysters on the half shell. Reverse HH 10 PM to close.  Value priced wine list. Well selected. Well selected craft beers as well.  Very friendly off Strip service.  A great HH spot that rolls seamlessly into a full-blown dinner.  Recommended.

FtG3CduDghsBaF_sk8YLNw.text: Third visit in 2 weeks? You could say I'm a fan. Chef Jaime Tran has created a menu of Vietnamese-American that is sophisticated enough for a celebratory dinner or date night, but approachable enough for a Thursday evening when you don't want to cook.   I've tried many items on the menu and my favorites are the adorable bao sliders, the west coast oysters (the r month rule has been shucked recently if you hadn't heard), the mesculn greens salad with charred  apricot, the short rib, and the hanger steak.   The hanger steak is the very best I've eaten anywhere, including my own kitchen, and I can make a mean steak. The combination of the meat with the street corn is incredible. And speaking of incredible, that's also how I would describe the short rib, and the ratatouille and yucca gnocchi it's served with. Ideal scenario is for my husband to order one and let me order the other so I can have a little bit of both, because after having both, I don't want to have to choose!  Service is excellent; the staff is super attentive without being obtrusive. The Common Law cocktail is spectacular, and the wine list is fantastic.   I've been here under 3 sets of dining circumstances, most recently celebrating my 13th wedding anniversary. I look forward to many more meals at The Black Sheep.

x2YahhtgQWjtv0hbl9wO2g.text: My wife and I went here last month and, I have to say, it was pretty darn fantastic. We had the persimmons goat cheese salad to start, which still gets me going -- the cheese is spread onto the plate, which means that every bite has this deliciousness. The beef crisps were insanely good. Perfect start to the meal. We shared the scallops for the main course, and they were to die for. This is definitely one of the best restaurants in Vegas.

Uw6SFO3oJVR5XtsqL2vYVQ.text: Came here for date night dinner and was not let down. We are notorious for sharing everything when we eat so we're able to try a variety of things in one sitting. Most of the time we just order every appetizer and are too full or order a main dish.   We tried the hamachi which was just okay, the tuna which I think needs a little citrus to brighten it, the octopus--the texture threw me off but my boyfriend liked it, and lastly the Vietnamese rolls which he thought were too fatty/greasy but I liked. If all of the apps were amazing they'd win me over completely and it would be our go to date night spot since it's off the strip, and just a few freeway exits away from home.  The salmon clay pot and drinks are what killed the night for us. The clay pot was so amazing. We asked the server which of the main dishes he liked best and went off of his recommendation (which we were probably going to order anyway.) Mushrooms and farro are staples in our daily diet but this was just cooked perfectly. The salmon prepared medium rare was so tender and flavorful that I almost thought about ordering another one just to be gluttonous. To drink my boyfriend had two negronies. A rare thing because he's usually very picky with how they're prepared. I had the Green Lightning with matcha and gin, followed by the Sunburn with Hangar 1 mandarin blossom, aperol, & ginger lemonade. Both were really good.   I just made my "much too good for children" chocolate cake over the weekend so we decided to skip dessert which we never do, but the next time we come, it sounds like their tres leches cake is a must!

W46OXYlcaN5rUiGb__EvbA.text: Are you kidding me, amazing food and it's great for locals. I am in and they are playing gangster and nas....  Hunter is so bomb, hes. Vegan that knows meat.  (I know that sounds innaproperate)

qqo77u7UM0LBIYIZAn3YLg.text: First off, can we talk about how cute they plate their food?? I think you can find my pics but I don't know. Anyhow, my friends and I happened to go on the last day of restaurant week. So you got an app, entree, and dessert, ALL WITH A WINE PAIRING for $40. So ok BOMBDIGGITY DEALIO. So, I got the egg rolls, short rib, and macaroons. I love fried food, so egg rolls were bomb. I just wish they didn't put the fish sauce on the egg rolls bc I don't like TOO much fish sauce but whatev - it was still hot and crunchy and delicious. The short rib was a little dry but the veggies and gnocchi around it was moist enough that if you had all 3 on your fork it was an even distribution of moist and flavor.   I did not like the macaroons. There was something in there that kinda made my mouth feel numb? I don't know. It was weird. I've had a lot of macaroons in my time and these were def my least fav.   My friends got the hanger steak? They all cleaned their plates so I assume they hated it (insert sarcastic font). Anyways, cute new spot (with the most atrocious parking situation) in the southwest side. Def worth checking out even if you're going to the small little bar for a drinky drink.

6rr-oTzrKRmLrf0RxlDeNg.text: Hands down some of the most creative and flavorful tapas dishes I've had in Vegas !  This restaurant has a contemporary design that is aesthetically pleasing. Beautiful bar set up and cool vibe . We had the tuna cracker, hamachi, chicken wings, tomato and watermelon salad, calamari,  salmon entree, and tres leches cake. Everything was so tasty, and full of complementary flavors . All the ingredients, spices, herbs came together wonderfully. I enjoyed everything it is hard to say what was my favorite. We ended with their only dessert - chocolate tres leches. With a dessert like that you really don't need more . It was incredible ! I can't wait to go back - def on my list of favorites !

_xg0tcDpZc9J_8PjNKrtCw.text: Genuinely confused how this place has received such stellar reviews.   I'll be frank: service is good, the food is MEDIOCRE. Very very mediocre. The short rib and pork belly are the highlights of their entree and everything else is simply not worth the money (I've tried 5 entrees).   My opinion: way better food for way better prices at OTHER establishments. The Black Sheep is definitely a disappointing place.

7EhRcbreNvscU-3pMXogLA.text: Rustic feel, very small but nice, pretty crowded. We were there from 5:45pm-7pm. Service was great! Our waiter noticed our table was wobbly on his own & immediately fixed then started to explain everything on the menu, drinks, popular items & what he highly recommends, very attentive & nice throughout our entire time there.   Small menu with a different type of food items, original/one of a kind. My only complaint, which could be our fault for not catching happy hour was we wanted to try out several different starters & share (just two of us) dishes were very small & pricey. 4 appetizers, 2 cocktails, over $60 & we left still a little hungry.  I'll be back for a light snack or to try a full entree or if ever just want to grab a drink.

Dt_mJ1MjMjjIsjhO67bS-w.text: Great quality food, Vietnamese fusion but at a high price. This place is meant for a splurge and for a change from the usual Vietnamese fare in town.  Unique cocktail menu is alluring. The appetizers are all good: burrata salad, ceviche and especially the octopus. Interesting ingredients in unexpected combinations.  Main dishes don't disappoint and desserts satisfying. Definitely worth checking out but it ain't cheap.

TEGgqFmgcAYD0HY7p2NDAg.text: Good stuff. Oyster happy hour is reason alone! Mignonette(the ONLY way to eat half shells) served, plus a really subtle spicy lemon grass dip.   We also tried the octopus starter- the curry was just right!   Max is super friendly, and perfectly attentive.   Looking forward to coming by for a proper meal!

e6JuunQp4m8IjNAKOJrkng.text: What a pleasure to go to a place where from A to Z everything is perfect. Service and food is spotless, prices are great as well. I am glad they have full bar.
